lace: a fine open fabric, typically one of cotton or silk, made by looping, twisting, or knitting thread in patterns and used especially for trimming garments.
chain: a connected flexible series of metal links used for fastening or securing objects and pulling or supporting loads
USB drive: A drive designed to be connected to a computer through a USB port; specifically = "USB flash drive".
money: a current medium of exchange in the form of coins and banknotes; coins and banknotes collectively
iPod: a small electronic device for playing and storing digital audio and video files.
paper: material manufactured in thin sheets from the pulp of wood or other fibrous substances, used for writing, drawing, or printing on, or as wrapping material
radio: the transmission and reception of electromagnetic waves of radio frequency, especially those carrying sound messages
mp3: a means of compressing a sound sequence into a very small file, to enable digital storage and transmission.
keyboard: a panel of keys that operate a computer or typewriter.
chair: a separate seat for one person, typically with a back and four legs.
milk: an opaque white fluid rich in fat and protein, secreted by female mammals for the nourishment of their young
thermostat: a device that automatically regulates temperature, or that activates a device when the temperature reaches a certain point.
clipper: an instrument for cutting or trimming small pieces off things
lampshade: a cover for a lamp, used to soften or direct its light.
sandal: a light shoe with either an openwork upper or straps attaching the sole to the foot
cinder block: a lightweight building brick made from small cinders mixed with sand and cement.
monitor: A computer monitor is an output device which displays information in pictorial form. A monitor usually comprises the display device, circuitry, casing, and power supply.
tire: a rubber covering, typically inflated or surrounding an inflated inner tube, placed around a wheel to form a flexible contact with the road.
cup: a small bowl-shaped container for drinking from, typically having a handle.
peanut: the oval seed of a South American plant, widely roasted and salted and eaten as a snack.
backpack: a bag with shoulder straps that allow it to be carried on one's back.
drive: a trip or journey in a car
window: an opening in the wall or roof of a building or vehicle that is fitted with glass or other transparent material in a frame to admit light or air and allow people to see out.
tape: a narrow strip of material, typically used to hold or fasten something
glow stick: a novelty item consisting of a plastic tube containing two chemicals which combine when the tube is bent, so producing a luminescent glow.
pad: the soft dull sound of steady steps
piano: a passage marked to be performed softly.
carton: a light box or container, typically one made of waxed cardboard or plastic in which drinks or foodstuffs are packaged
sauce: thick liquid served with food, usually savory dishes, to add moistness and flavor
plate: a flat dish, typically circular and made of china, from which food is eaten or served.
cube: a symmetrical three-dimensional shape, either solid or hollow, contained by six equal squares.
sharpie: a sharp-prowed, flat-bottomed New England sailboat, with one or two masts each rigged with a triangular sail.
food: any nutritious substance that people or animals eat or drink or that plants absorb in order to maintain life and growth
blanket: a large piece of woolen or similar material used as a bed covering or other covering for warmth.
mop: an autumn fair or gathering at which farmhands and servants were hired.
stop: a cessation of movement or operation
vase: a decorative container, typically made of glass or china and used as an ornament or for displaying cut flowers.
band: a group of people who have a common interest or purpose
spoon: an implement consisting of a small, shallow oval or round bowl on a long handle, used for eating, stirring, and serving food.
grid: a framework of spaced bars that are parallel to or cross each other; a grating
outlet: a pipe or hole through which water or gas may escape.
desk: a piece of furniture with a flat or sloped surface and typically with drawers, at which one can read, write, or do other work.
press: a forcible enlistment of men, especially for the navy.
towel: a piece of thick absorbent cloth or paper used for drying oneself or wiping things dry.
bread: food made of flour, water, and yeast or another leavening agent, mixed together and baked
wagon: a vehicle used for transporting goods or another specified purpose
lip gloss: a cosmetic applied to the lips to provide a glossy finish, often tinted.
sofa: a long upholstered seat with a back and arms, for two or more people
button: a small disk or knob sewn on to a garment, either to fasten it by being pushed through a slit made for the purpose or for decoration
bracelet: an ornamental band, hoop, or chain worn on the wrist or arm.
greeting: a polite word or sign of welcome or recognition
candy: a sweet food made with sugar or syrup combined with fruit, chocolate, or nuts
perfume: a fragrant liquid typically made from essential oils extracted from flowers and spices, used to impart a pleasant smell to one's body or clothes
magnet: a piece of iron (or an ore, alloy, or other material) that has its component atoms so ordered that the material exhibits properties of magnetism, such as attracting other iron-containing objects or aligning itself in an external magnetic field.
bag: a container made of flexible material with an opening at the top, used for carrying things
chapter book: A book containing records relating to an ecclesiastical chapter or (later) to a branch of a secular organization or society.
sponge: a primitive sedentary aquatic invertebrate with a soft porous body that is typically supported by a framework of fibers or calcareous or glassy spicules. Sponges draw in a current of water to extract nutrients and oxygen.
clay: a stiff, sticky fine-grained earth, typically yellow, red, or bluish-gray in color and often forming an impermeable layer in the soil. It can be molded when wet, and is dried and baked to make bricks, pottery, and ceramics.
leg warmers: a pair of tubular knitted garments designed to cover the leg from ankle to knee or thigh, typically worn by dancers during rehearsal.
tray: a flat, shallow container with a raised rim, typically used for carrying food and drink, or for holding small items
glasses: a pair of lenses set in a frame resting on the nose and ears, used to correct or assist defective eyesight or protect the eyes.
clamp: a heap of potatoes or other root vegetables stored under straw or earth.
sketch: a rough or unfinished drawing or painting, often made to assist in making a more finished picture
hanger: a wood on the side of a steep hill.
doll: a temporary barrier on a racetrack.
house: a building for human habitation, especially one that is lived in by a family or small group of people.
frame: a rigid structure that surrounds or encloses something such as a door or window.
packet: a paper or cardboard container, typically one in which goods are packed to be sold
seat: a thing made or used for sitting on, such as a chair or stool.
hair: any of the fine threadlike strands growing from the skin of humans, mammals, and some other animals.
computer: an electronic device for storing and processing data, typically in binary form, according to instructions given to it in a variable program.
video: the recording, reproducing, or broadcasting of moving visual images.
mirror: a reflective surface, now typically of glass coated with a metal amalgam, that reflects a clear image.
candle: a cylinder or block of wax or tallow with a central wick that is lit to produce light as it burns.
air: the invisible gaseous substance surrounding the earth, a mixture mainly of oxygen and nitrogen.
out: a way of escaping from a problem or dilemma
album: a blank book for the insertion of photographs, stamps, or pictures
canvas: a strong, coarse unbleached cloth made from hemp, flax, cotton, or a similar yarn, used to make items such as sails and tents and as a surface for oil painting
flower: the seed-bearing part of a plant, consisting of reproductive organs (stamens and carpels) that are typically surrounded by a brightly colored corolla (petals) and a green calyx (sepals).
air freshener: a substance or device for making the air in a room smell fresh or clean.
tissue: any of the distinct types of material of which animals or plants are made, consisting of specialized cells and their products
clock: an ornamental pattern woven or embroidered on the side of a stocking or sock near the ankle.
sun: the star around which the earth orbits.
water bottle: A bottle or flask used to carry drinking water, especially when travelling, often made of glass or (in later use) plastic.
sand: a loose granular substance, typically pale yellowish brown, resulting from the erosion of siliceous and other rocks and forming a major constituent of beaches, riverbeds, the seabed, and deserts.
ice: an entry stored in a person's mobile phone that provides emergency contact information
cell: a small room in which a prisoner is locked up or in which a monk or nun sleeps.
lights: the lungs of sheep or pigs used as food, especially for pets.
machine: an apparatus using or applying mechanical power and having several parts, each with a definite function and together performing a particular task
knife: an instrument composed of a blade fixed into a handle, used for cutting or as a weapon.
leg: each of the limbs on which a person or animal walks and stands
tree: a woody perennial plant, typically having a single stem or trunk growing to a considerable height and bearing lateral branches at some distance from the ground.
ipod: a portable electronic device for playing and storing digital audio and video files.
rug: a floor covering of thick woven material or animal skin, typically not extending over the entire floor.
cork: a county in the Republic of Ireland, in the province of Munster, on the Celtic Sea.
toothbrush: a small brush with a long handle, used for cleaning the teeth.
packing: the action or process of packing something
cookie: a small sweet cake, typically round, flat, and crisp.
web: a set of related web pages located under a single domain name.
key: a low-lying island or reef, especially in the Caribbean.
lotion: a thick, smooth liquid preparation designed to be applied to the skin for medicinal or cosmetic purposes
shoe: a covering for the foot, typically made of leather, having a sturdy sole and not reaching above the ankle.
sidewalk: a paved path for pedestrians at the side of a road.
card: a toothed implement or machine used to comb and clean raw fibers before spinning.
mp3 player: a device for playing MP3s or other digital audio files
chapter: a main division of a book, typically with a number or title.
water: a colorless, transparent, odorless liquid that forms the seas, lakes, rivers, and rain and is the basis of the fluids of living organisms.
thread: a long, thin strand of cotton, nylon, or other fibers used in sewing or weaving.
headphones: a pair of earphones joined by a band placed over the head, for listening to audio signals such as music or speech
bow: the front end of a ship
credit: the ability of a customer to obtain goods or services before payment, based on the trust that payment will be made in the future
menu: a list of dishes available in a restaurant.
soda: carbonated water (originally made with sodium bicarbonate) drunk alone or with liquor or wine
credit card: a small plastic card issued by a bank, business, etc., allowing the holder to purchase goods or services on credit
cinder: a small piece of partly burned coal or wood that has stopped giving off flames but still has combustible matter in it.
clothes: items worn to cover the body
block: a large solid piece of hard material, especially rock, stone, or wood, typically with flat surfaces on each side
ballpoint: a pen with a tiny ball as its writing point. The ball transfers ink from a cartridge to the paper.
shovel: a tool with a broad flat blade and typically upturned sides, used for moving coal, earth, snow or other material.
apple: the round fruit of a tree of the rose family, which typically has thin red or green skin and crisp flesh. Many varieties have been developed as dessert or cooking fruit or for making cider.
seat belt: a belt or strap securing a person to prevent injury, especially in a vehicle or aircraft.
soap: a substance used with water for washing and cleaning, made of a compound of natural oils or fats with sodium hydroxide or another strong alkali, and typically having perfume and coloring added
pot: a shot aimed at someone or something; a potshot
speaker: a person who speaks.
slipper: a comfortable slip-on shoe that is worn indoors.
wash: an act of washing something or an instance of being washed.
puddle: a small pool of liquid, especially of rainwater on the ground
fake: a thing that is not genuine; a forgery or sham
soy: protein derived from soybeans, used as a replacement for animal protein in foods and fodder.
table: a piece of furniture with a flat top and one or more legs, providing a level surface on which objects may be placed, and that can be used for such purposes as eating, writing, working, or playing games.
ring: an act of causing a bell to sound, or the resonant sound caused by this
belt: a strip of leather or other material worn around the waist or across the chest, especially in order to support clothes or carry weapons
eye: each of a pair of globular organs in the head through which people and vertebrate animals see, the visible part typically appearing almond-shaped in animals with eyelids
bookmark: a strip of leather, cardboard, or other material used to mark one's place in a book.
toothpaste: a paste used on a toothbrush for cleaning the teeth
gloss: a translation or explanation of a word or phrase.
wrapper: a piece of paper, plastic, or foil covering and protecting something sold
plastic: a synthetic material made from a wide range of organic polymers such as polyethylene, PVC, nylon, etc., that can be molded into shape while soft and then set into a rigid or slightly elastic form.
paint: a colored substance which is spread over a surface and dries to leave a thin decorative or protective coating
checkbook: a book of blank checks with a register for recording checks written.
spring: the season after winter and before summer, in which vegetation begins to appear, in the northern hemisphere from March to May and in the southern hemisphere from September to November
drumstick: a stick, typically with a shaped or padded head, used for beating a drum.
nail file: a strip of roughened metal or an emery board used for smoothing and shaping the fingernails and toenails.
banana: a long curved fruit which grows in clusters and has soft pulpy flesh and yellow skin when ripe.
toe: any of the five digits at the end of the human foot
fork: an implement with two or more prongs used for lifting food to the mouth or holding it when cutting.
box: a slow-growing European evergreen shrub or small tree with glossy dark green leaves. It is often grown as a hedge and for topiary.
door: a hinged, sliding, or revolving barrier at the entrance to a building, room, or vehicle, or in the framework of a cupboard
eraser: an object, typically a piece of soft rubber or plastic, used to rub out something written.
shawl: a piece of fabric worn by women over the shoulders or head or wrapped around a baby.
needle: a very fine slender piece of metal with a point at one end and a hole or eye for thread at the other, used in sewing.
glass: a hard, brittle substance, typically transparent or translucent, made by fusing sand with soda, lime, and sometimes other ingredients and cooling rapidly. It is used to make windows, drinking containers, and other articles
flag: a plant with sword-shaped leaves that grow from a rhizome.
stick: a thin piece of wood that has fallen or been cut from a tree.
sign: an object, quality, or event whose presence or occurrence indicates the probable presence or occurrence of something else
nail: a small metal spike with a broadened flat head, driven typically into wood with a hammer to join things together or to serve as a peg or hook.
television: a system for transmitting visual images and sound that are reproduced on screens, chiefly used to broadcast programs for entertainment, information, and education.
player: a person taking part in a sport or game
car: a road vehicle, typically with four wheels, powered by an internal combustion engine and able to carry a small number of people
cap: a kind of soft, flat hat without a brim and typically with a visor.
shampoo: a liquid preparation containing detergent or soap for washing the hair
bed: a piece of furniture for sleep or rest, typically a framework with a mattress and coverings
cat: a small domesticated carnivorous mammal with soft fur, a short snout, and retractable claws. It is widely kept as a pet or for catching mice, and many breeds have been developed.
chalk: a soft white limestone (calcium carbonate) formed from the skeletal remains of sea creatures.
wallet: a pocket-sized, flat, folding holder for money and plastic cards.
note: a brief record of facts, topics, or thoughts, written down as an aid to memory
street: a public road in a city or town, typically with houses and buildings on one or both sides
rubber band: a loop of stretchy rubber for holding things together.
drill: a coarse twilled cotton or linen fabric
newspaper: a printed publication (usually issued daily or weekly) consisting of folded unstapled sheets and containing news, feature articles, advertisements, and correspondence
playing card: each of a set of rectangular pieces of cardboard or other material with an identical pattern on one side and different numbers and symbols on the other, used to play various games, some involving gambling. A standard deck contains 52 cards divided into four suits.
toilet: a fixed receptacle into which a person may urinate or defecate, typically consisting of a large bowl connected to a system for flushing away the waste into a sewer or septic tank
pencil: an instrument for writing or drawing, consisting of a thin stick of graphite or a similar substance enclosed in a long thin piece of wood or fixed in a metal or plastic case.
deodorant: a substance which removes or conceals unpleasant smells, especially bodily odors.
purse: a small bag used especially by a woman to carry everyday personal items.
site: an area of ground on which a town, building, or monument is constructed
sticky: (in an online forum) a thread containing important information that is set to remain at the top of the other threads regardless of when it was last updated
greeting card: a decorative card sent to convey good wishes on some occasion.
drawer: a box-shaped storage compartment without a lid, made to slide horizontally in and out of a desk, chest, or other piece of furniture.
carrot: a tapering orange-colored root eaten as a vegetable.
washing: the action of washing oneself or laundering clothes, bed linen, etc.
file: pounded or powdered sassafras leaves used to flavor and thicken soup, especially gumbo.
conditioner: a substance or appliance used to improve or maintain something's condition
tooth: each of a set of hard, bony enamel-coated structures in the jaws of most vertebrates, used for biting and chewing.
mouse: a computer mouse is a hand-held pointing device that detects two-dimensional motion relative to a surface.
helmet: a hard or padded protective hat, various types of which are worn by soldiers, police officers, firefighters, motorcyclists, athletes, and others.
shirt: a garment for the upper body made of cotton or a similar fabric, with a collar, sleeves, and buttons down the front.
floor: the lower surface of a room, on which one may walk
balloon: a brightly colored rubber sac inflated with air and then sealed at the neck, used as a children's toy or a decoration.
bowl: a ball made slightly asymmetrical so that it runs on a curved course, used in the game of lawn bowling.
freshener: a substance or device that makes something fresher or cleaner
couch: a coarse grass with long creeping roots, which can be troublesome in lawns and gardens.
rubber: a contest consisting of a series of successive matches (typically three or five) between the same sides or people in tennis, cricket, and other games.
lamp: a device for giving light, either one consisting of an electric bulb together with its holder and shade or cover, or one burning gas or a liquid fuel and consisting of a wick or mantle and a glass shade
book: a written or printed work consisting of pages glued or sewn together along one side and bound in covers
lip: either of the two fleshy parts which form the upper and lower edges of the opening of the mouth
boom: a spar pivoting on the after side of the mast and to which the foot of a vessel's sail is attached, allowing the angle of the sail to be changed.
thermometer: an instrument for measuring and indicating temperature, typically one consisting of a narrow, hermetically sealed glass tube marked with graduations and having at one end a bulb containing mercury or alcohol that expands and contracts in the tube with heating and cooling.
tie: a piece of string, cord, or the like used for fastening or tying something
drill press: a machine tool for drilling holes, set on a fixed stand.
rusty nail: A strong, sweet cocktail made with Scotch whisky and Drambuie liqueur, and served with ice and sometimes a twist of lemon.
screw: a short, slender, sharp-pointed metal pin with a raised helical thread running around it and a slotted head, used to join things together by being rotated so that it pierces wood or other material and is held tightly in place.
watch: a small timepiece worn typically on a strap on one's wrist.
swing: a seat suspended by ropes or chains, on which someone may sit and swing back and forth.
controller: a person or thing that directs or regulates something
zipper: a device consisting of two flexible strips of metal or plastic with interlocking projections closed or opened by pulling a slide along them, used to fasten garments, bags, and other items.
cell phone: a phone with access to a cellular radio system so it can be used over a wide area, without a physical connection to a network; a mobile phone.
chocolate: a food preparation in the form of a paste or solid block made from roasted and ground cacao seeds, typically sweetened
pool: a supply of vehicles or goods available for use when needed
glow: a steady radiance of light or heat
tomato: a glossy red, or occasionally yellow, pulpy edible fruit that is eaten as a vegetable or in salad.
mouse pad: a piece of rigid or slightly resilient material on which a computer mouse is moved.
phone: a speech sound; the smallest discrete segment of sound in a stream of speech.
charger: a large, flat dish; a platter.
boom box: a portable sound system, typically including radio and cassette or CD player, capable of powerful sound
washing machine: a machine for washing clothes, bed linens, etc.
liner: a lining in an appliance, device, or container, especially a removable one.
rubber duck: an inflatable flat-bottomed rubber dinghy, typically motorized.
face: the front part of a person's head from the forehead to the chin, or the corresponding part in an animal.
bottle: a container, typically made of glass or plastic and with a narrow neck, used for storing drinks or other liquids
telephone: a system for transmitting voices over a distance using wire or radio, by converting acoustic vibrations to electrical signals
model: a three-dimensional representation of a person or thing or of a proposed structure, typically on a smaller scale than the original
scotch: a cut or score in skin or another surface
